Before you reach out to contact us, did you know that our website is way different (and we say way better!) than every other storm shutters website out there? Not only are our prices lower than everybody else but they are also right on our website for everyone to see! You most likely can order everything yourself..you don't need to wait for us for a quote...we have made it super easy for everyone to do! Now we don't want you to think we don't want to talk to you because we do! We just feel bad when we can't get to you as soon as possible. When hurricane season rolls around we get tons of calls so we will inevitably get behind on returning your call..we don't want that and you don't want that! We are always happy to answer all questions you have or help you with you order! Hurricane Shutters Near Me - Lowest Prices on the Planet - Call us today. Contact Hurricane Shutters Wholesale Please fill out the form below if you need assistance. PRIVATE EVENT Saturday, October 26, 2019 11:00 AM 9:00 PM 11:00 21:00 Hurricane Alley (map) Google Calendar ICS VIP PIRATE FEST PRIVATE EVENT WHEN: SATURDAY, OCTOBER 26 (11AM-9PM) $100 TICKET INCLUDES DRINK AND FOOD • CLOSED TO THE PUBLIC • • LIVE MUSIC BY JERRY LEEMAN • • FREE TASTING BY JACK APPLE AND RUM HAVEN • • $100 GIFT CARD FOR BEST PIRATE • TICKETS AVAILABLE AT THE RESTAURANT FOR MORE INFORMATION CALL: (561) 364-4008 View Event → PLEASE NOTE:* Regarding the safety of these items, written information is available upon request. * Consuming raw or undercooked meats poultry seafood shellfish or eggs may increase your risk of foodborne illness, especially if you have certain medical conditions. There is a risk associated with consuming raw oysters. If you have chronic illness of the liver stomach or blood or have immune disorders, you are a greater risk of serious illness from raw oysters and should eat oysters fully cooked. If unsure of your risk consult a physician. Health inspection reports available upon request. Contact Us Full Name (Required) Company Name (Required) Email Address (Required) Phone Number (Required) More information CAPTCHA Linkedin X-twitter Instagram Youtube Solutions IOSS HS Code Classification Duty & Tax Calculation Prohibited & Restricted Goods Screening Denied Parties Screening ICS2 Second Release IOSS HS Code Classification Duty & Tax Calculation Prohibited & Restricted Goods Screening Denied Parties Screening ICS2 Second Release Products Kona Zephyr Matcing Engine Aura Calculation & Compliance Engine Kona Zephyr Matcing Engine Aura Calculation & Compliance Engine Information Case Studies Sectors Resources Why Hurricane Case Studies Sectors Resources Why Hurricane Contact info@hurricanecommerce.com Registered Office 4 Grovelands, Boundary Way Hemel Hempstead, HP2 7TE Office Rothersthorpe House, 4 Billing Rd, Northampton, NN1 5AN Copyright © 2025 All Rights Reserved. | Terms | Privacy Policy Scroll to Top Homepage Why Hurricane Solutions IOSS HS Code Classification Duty & Tax Calculation Prohibited & Restricted Goods Screening Denied Parties Screening ICS2 Second Release Products Kona Zephyr Matching Engine Aura Calculation & Compliance Engine Sectors Carriers Retailers Customs Brokers Freight Forwarders Postal Operators Marketplaces Carrier Management Systems Airlines Professional Services Case Studies Resources Blogs Latest News Podcasts Videos Hamburger Toggle Menu Get in touch David SpoTtiswood Co-founder Interesting Fact: I am an amateur baker, but I still have no idea how sourduogh starter actually works, and am intrigued how it all reacts together to produce an incredible taste. Favourite Music: November Rain by Guns ‘n’ Roses.  Going to Wembley with my wife our go to fun thing in our early years, our youth with long hair and rock clothing and not a care in the world other than getting the best spot in the house. Favourite Quote: “Insanity is doing the same thing over and over again, and expecting different results ” – Albert Einstein Harry Reilly Non-exec Interesting Fact: I learned Arabic for five years!. Favourite Music: A Long December by Counting Crows.  Memory of best family time together in California. Favourite Quote: “Don’t forget execution, boys. It’s the all-important last 95%” Tom Lee Technical Director Interesting Fact: I am completely self-taught from a technical skills persepctiuve, and left formal education at 18. Favourite Music: Blink 182 – Aliens Exist.  Brings back fond memories of stickly floors and cheap beer. Favourite Quote: “He sprayed water in my face – thta’s not allowed” – James Haskell.  The whole event surrounding it is hilarious and shows the power of a good wind up Martin Palmer Co-Founder Interesting Fact: I started my working life training to be an accountant but decided I hated numbers. (Ironically I now love them!). I really wanted to join the Hong Kong Police force but couldn’t do that until i was 24. I took a temporary job in Imports and 47 years later here I am. Favourite Music: There only was one choice. Harry Chapin. Meant a lot to me in my early years as an import broker. We played Chapin for hours and this one seemed to cover so many modes. Favourite Quote: “No man is an island” Neil Harmer Operations Director Interesting Fact: As a Geologist my idea of the perfect beach holiday is going to the beach and investigating the rocks in the cliffs behind. Favourite Music: Broken Stones – Paul Weller, I’m a huge Paul Weller / The Jam fan; Broken Stones is a very relaxing song, I love the use of the electric piano in it Favourite Quote: “Don’t put off until tomorrow what you can do today”. This is a great quote by Benjamin Franklin, to have in your head when working through a series of tasks to help keep focused. Robert Dundas Sales Director Interesting Fact: One of my life goals is to be able to speak French, I’ve been doing Duolingo every day for the last five years, and I’m still rubbish! Favourite Music: Where do I even start! Tom Petty Running Down a Dream, this is my top-down driving next to the ocean song Favourite Quote: “This time will pass” ASHLEY DEXTER CFO & Co-founder Interesting Fact: I was nearly named Battle Dexter (I would have probably now been residing in one of His Majesty’s establishments) Favourite Music: Even though I spent a few years in the music industry my taste of music was always a cause for concern with my colleagues, so to surprise them all my current favourite is Kids by MGMT (absolute belter) Favourite Quote: “Quitters never win and winners never quit” Ian Venner CTO & Co-founder Interesting Fact: Runs Red Lantern Records, a not-for-profit, ethical label as a side project, whose artists have regular national BBC radio airplay. Favourite Music: Tom Waits, pretty much all of his work.  Beautifully observed avante-garde vignettes of life.  Oh, and anything really loud! Favourite Quote: “It’s not the mountains we climb, but the grit in our shoe that grinds us down” – which sums up taking a business from start-up to enterprise. Martyn Noble CEO & Co-founder Interesting Fact: Played a high standard of semi-professional rugby union (too many years ago now!) Favourite Music: Led Zeppelin – Stairway to Heaven…my first live gig – Knebworth 11th August 1979, the track never grows old and is the iconic song of ‘hope’ whatever mood you are in when listening too it…and I’m still trying to work out what the lyrics mean!! Favourite Quote: “Know your customers, Know your People, Know your Numbers” – plagiarised from Sir John Harvey Jones when I met him very early on in my career and values I stick to in my business life.

Longtime Boynton restaurant navigates city's redevelopment project Watch Now Menu Local National Weather Sports Traffic Watch Now Watch Now Close × Live Watch Alerts Search site Go Weather Interactive Radar Daily Forecast Hurricane Survival Guide Hourly Forecast Live Interactive VIPIR Hurricane Map Weather Cams News Local News WPTV Investigates Real Estate News Politics State National News World News Crime Education Protecting Paradise Your Health Matters Traffic Gas Prices Gas Availability Airports Entertainment WPTV Schedule, Other TV Listings Movies Life Finding Florida Shining A Light Underdog Pets Family Food News Sports Panthers Dolphins College Sports FAU Hurricanes Gators Seminoles Cognizant Classic Football Baseball Basketball Surfing Blog Recreation Sports Money Money Headlines Dont Waste Your Money Recalls Marketplace Sunshine Spotlight Home Experts In the Know Videos WPTV Livestream Player WPTV on Youtube About Us Advertise Contact Us WPTV Schedule, Other TV Listings Contests Jobs Staff Bios WHDT, South Florida's 9 How to Watch WPTV 24/7 Support Sign In Newsletters Sign Out Manage Emails Apps Careers Search WPTV5 wptv WPTV UC0bCUnP5RrkJZUtd3bBz6Kw @wptv5 1 WX Alerts 1 Closings/Delays Treasure Coast Okeechobee Indian River St. Lucie Martin Palm Beach County North PBC Central PBC South PBC The Glades Broward Miami-Dade More + Quick Links + Treasure Coast Okeechobee Indian River St. Lucie Martin Palm Beach County North PBC Central PBC South PBC The Glades Broward Miami-Dade News Palm Beach County Region S Palm Beach County Boynton Beach Actions Facebook Tweet Email Longtime Boynton Beach restaurant navigates city redevelopment in effort to continue operations Community Redevelopment Agency works to keep local businesses Prev Next Hurricane Alley restaurant has been serving residents for decades at its location on Federal Highway and Ocean Avenue in Boynton Beach. By: Miranda Christian Posted and last updated BOYNTON BEACH, Fla. — Hurricane Alley restaurant has been serving residents for decades at its location on Federal Highway and Ocean Avenue in Boynton Beach. Owner Kim Kelly said they have stayed out through tough times. MORE: Boynton Beach to look at development ideas for Federal Highway "We have survived a lot of obstacles throughout the 25 years, road closures, buildings, COVID. You name it, we have pretty much survived it," Kelly said. Kelly said she has seen the city grow but wasn't expecting her landlords to sell the property. "You gotta be silly if you don't think that somebody's going to be affected and unfortunately it will probably be us," Kelly said. WPTV Hurricane Alley owner Kim Kelly talks about Boynton Beach's redevelopment plans. The owners of a stretch of buildings along Ocean Avenue are selling to the Community Redevelopment Agency for $3.6 million. The move was made because it ties into a redevelopment project located behind Hurricane Alley. "With it being the corner piece here in the downtown. It makes more sense for it to face Ocean [Avenue] as well," said Boynton Beach Commissioner Christina Romelus. Romelus said the CRA is currently looking for a developer for the project. Kelly made a plea to the CRA on Tuesday to keep her business a part of the future plans. WPTV Boynton Beach Commissioner Christina Romelus speaks about prioritizing local businesses amid the city's redevelopment. "We are going to go with the growth," Kelly said. Romelus said the CRA wants to keep local businesses in Boynton Beach and will work with the renters who are already here. "We want to keep them here, and Miss Kim Kelly, of course, falls right into that purview, and we will do everything in our power to support her," Romelus said. "[I] got some reassurance that Hurricane Alley is downtown, and we are here to stay," Kelly said. Kelly said she now hopes the city can find the perfect project for this section of downtown. CRA staff said they will continue to work with the property owner to come to a sale agreement. Once that is complete, it will be brought back to the CRA board. Copyright 2021 Scripps Media, Inc. All rights reserved. This material may not be published, broadcast, rewritten, or redistributed. Why owner of Hurricane Alley fears her popular Boynton restaurant could close (and it's not because of COVID) News Sports Restaurants Real Estate Opinion Advertise Obituaries eNewspaper Legals LOCAL Why owner of Hurricane Alley fears her popular Boynton restaurant could close (and it’s not because of COVID) Jorge Milian Palm Beach Post BOYNTON BEACH — Kim Kelly has been serving up steamed oysters, conch fritters and huge sandwiches - the soft shell crab is to die for - at her downtown restaurant in Boynton Beach for nearly a quarter-century. Hurricane Alley, which Kelly opened in 1996, has become something of an institution in the city, combining the feel of a neighborhood sports bar with a Florida Keys vibe. But Kelly fears that the end may be near for Hurricane Alley. >> BOYNTON READERS: Sign up for The Post’s weekly Boynton Beach newsletter here A proposed mixed-use development project that includes 229 residences and 18,000 square feet of commercial space, will snuff the life out of her restaurant by swallowing up available parking for customers, Kelly said. “It could be the demise of us,” Kelly said. “We’re being suffocated.” To fight back, Kelly has started a Change.org petition demanding that Boynton’s Community Redevelopment Agency reject the $60 million project proposed by the developer, Ocean Avenue Residences and Shoppes, LLC. As of Thursday, the petition had received nearly 2,250 signatures. Kelly said she will also lead a march on Sept. 8 from Hurricane Alley, at 529 E. Ocean Avenue, to City Hall to coincide with the CRA’s monthly meeting. “We’ve been here fighting for the downtown for 25 years and now the CRA is going to develop it and we’re just going to be forgotten,” Kelly said. “That to me is a very sad day.” During a presentation at the CRA’s meeting Aug. 11, the developers said they planned for 544 parking spaces, including 120 for public parking. But critics of the project like resident Susan Oyer, whose family owns property in the immediate vicinity, said the development will take away scores of free parking spots that are now available to employees of area businesses and their customers. Hurricane Alley, which started in 1996 with two employees, now has 45 people on staff while Oyer’s properties have around 50 employees. “Those 120 parking spaces that you think you have [are] just going to be filled up mostly with employees,” Oyer said. And if those 120 parking spaces are not free, “You’re going to have a revolution,” Oyer warned. At the Aug. 11 meeting, the CRA accepted a letter of intent that gives the five-person body 90 days to negotiate terms of the deal with the developer. The CRA bought the property in 2018 for $3 million and leased a building on the two-acre parcel to the city for use as a temporary library during construction of Town Square. Board Chair Steven Grant is not in favor of the project because he feels the property could be put to better use, possibly as a future commuter train stop. While the majority of the board indicated they approved of the development, Grant said that “hopefully the CRA will rescind approval of the letter of intent because there’s too much discussion needed with the city, the county, the region about that location.“ Asked if he thought local businesses, including Hurricane Alley, would be negatively impacted, Grant said, “Absolutely.” He gets no argument from Kelly. She worries that much of her clientele, which includes a fair share of retirees, won’t fancy struggling to find parking and “will get frustrated and leave.” “We have so much residential [developments] already that people come down here and they don’t know where they can or can’t park,” Kelly said. “They’re worried they’re going to get towed or get a ticket so, rather than risk it, they just say, ‘I’m just going to go to some place where I can pull up and just walk in.’” Small business owners face an uphill battle in the best of times, and these are certainly not the best of times, especially for those trying to operate restaurants in the middle of the coronavirus pandemic. Kelly said she was closed for three weeks between March and April and then had limited hours and to-go service only until the beginning of May. In her petition, Kelly writes that the coronavirus “may not destroy us but the CRA just may!” “The struggle is definitely real,” Kelly said. “We’re just asking the CRA not to make the struggle impossible.” jmilian@pbpost.com @caneswatch Careers Staff Directory Accessibility Sitemap Legals Public notice certification Our Ethical Principles USA TODAY Network Style Guide Responsible Disclosure Subscription Terms & Conditions Advertiser Acceptance Policy Terms of Service Privacy Policy California Notice at Collection Your Privacy Choices Contact Us Support Local Business Advertise Your Business Promote your Event Buy and Sell Licensing & Reprints Help Center Palm Beach Post Store Subscriber Guide Manage Account Give Feedback Newspapers In Education Newsletters Facebook X eNewspaper Archives Jobs Real Estate Classifieds Shopping 10BEST LocaliQ Digital Marketing Solutions © 2025 www.palmbeachpost.com. All rights reserved.

Covid-19 Update — HURRICANE ALLEY Home About the Alley Alley Food Updated Hours Home Food Menus Drink Menu Happy Hour Special Events Find Us HURRICANE ALLEY Home About the Alley Alley Food Updated Hours Home Food Menus Drink Menu Happy Hour Special Events Find Us COVID-19 UPDATE First of all we’d like to thank all of our staff and Hurricane Alley patrons for their support during these difficult and uncharted times. We are optimistic that we will get through these challenging times. Secondly, we want to let everyone know that WE WILL BE OPENING FOR DINE-IN SERVICE ON MONDAY, MAY 11. We are following all guidelines and restrictions as instructed to do. We have management on duty to ask people to space apart at the the bar counter and we have removed bar chairs and tables to provide proper spacing to facilitate social distancing. We urge all other local restaurants and businesses to follow the same measures to protect all staff and patrons. THANKS TO ALL OF YOU THAT HELP SUPPORT SMALL BUSINESSES! Due to the Covid-19 virus, we are following the following CDC Guidelines: Social Distancing 50% Capacity Mandatory Ill staff or customers must leave IMMEDIATELY If you feel that you have to cough, remove yourself from the area Guidelines implemented by The Alley: No Raw Oysters or Clams One-Time Menus Extra hand-washing and glove use Everyday sanitation procedures and policies provided by DPBR PLEASE NOTE:* Regarding the safety of these items, written information is available upon request. * Consuming raw or undercooked meats poultry seafood shellfish or eggs may increase your risk of foodborne illness, especially if you have certain medical conditions. There is a risk associated with consuming raw oysters. If you have chronic illness of the liver stomach or blood or have immune disorders, you are a greater risk of serious illness from raw oysters and should eat oysters fully cooked. If unsure of your risk consult a physician. Health inspection reports available upon request. Where locals go to get away from it all and GET BLOWN AWAY! HOURS OF OPERATION: LUNCH & DINNER HOURS: Tuesday - Sunday: 11am - 10pm (Closed on Mondays) PHONE: (561) 364-4008 (Restaurant) (561) 364-4083 (Office) EMAIL: info@myhurricanealley.com LOCATION: 529 East Ocean Ave. Boynton Beach, FL 33435 DINE-IN TUESDAY-SUNDAY JUST SOME OF THE DELICIOUS FOOD WAITING FOR YOU AT THE ALLEY! HURRICANE HARVEY HOMEMADE SMOKED FISH DIP PEEL & EAT SHRIMP MAHI MAHI CAESAR SALAD ALL AMERICAN ALLEY CHEESEBURGER THE SURGE NEW ENGLAND ROLL SCALLOPS STEAMED CLAMS Press Release FOR IMMEDIATE RELEASE Hurricane Alley Raw Bar and Restaurant Receives 2020 Best of Boynton Beach Award Boynton Beach Award Program Honors the Achievement BOYNTON BEACH February 13, 2020 -- Hurricane Alley Raw Bar and Restaurant has been selected for the 2020 Best of Boynton Beach Award in the Local Business category by the Boynton Beach Award Program. Each year, the Boynton Beach Award Program identifies companies that we believe have achieved exceptional marketing success in their local community and business category. These are local companies that enhance the positive image of small business through service to their customers and our community. These exceptional companies help make the Boynton Beach area a great place to live, work and play. Various sources of information were gathered and analyzed to choose the winners in each category. The 2020 Boynton Beach Award Program focuses on quality, not quantity. Winners are determined based on the information gathered both internally by the Boynton Beach Award Program and data provided by third parties. About Boynton Beach Award Program The Boynton Beach Award Program is an annual awards program honoring the achievements and accomplishments of local businesses throughout the Boynton Beach area. Recognition is given to those companies that have shown the ability to use their best practices and implemented programs to generate competitive advantages and long-term value. The Boynton Beach Award Program was established to recognize the best of local businesses in our community. Our organization works exclusively with local business owners, trade groups, professional associations and other business advertising and marketing groups. Our mission is to recognize the small business community's contributions to the U.S. economy. SOURCE: Boynton Beach Award Program CONTACT: Boynton Beach Award Program Email: PublicRelations@2020-townrankingcontact.com URL: http://www.2020-townrankingcontact.com ### HURRICANE ALLEY VOTED TOP 20 BURGERS OF 2020 PLEASE NOTE:* Regarding the safety of these items, written information is available upon request. * Consuming raw or undercooked meats poultry seafood shellfish or eggs may increase your risk of foodborne illness, especially if you have certain medical conditions. There is a risk associated with consuming raw oysters. If you have chronic illness of the liver stomach or blood or have immune disorders, you are a greater risk of serious illness from raw oysters and should eat oysters fully cooked. If unsure of your risk consult a physician. Health inspection reports available upon request. TO GO ORDERS UPDATE — HURRICANE ALLEY Home About the Alley Alley Food Updated Hours Home Food Menus Drink Menu Happy Hour Special Events Find Us HURRICANE ALLEY Home About the Alley Alley Food Updated Hours Home Food Menus Drink Menu Happy Hour Special Events Find Us IMPORTANT UPDATE REGARDING TO GO ORDERS! Due to Florida being so busy with the influx of tourists and people receiving their Vaccines, we are being flooded with orders and therefore we do not take TO GO ORDERS over the phone. You may place an order at the bar. Also due to the shortage of workers because of stimulus and unemployment checks, we are short staffed and ticket times may be longer than normal.  We apologize for the inconvenience and hope to return soon to our regular practices. We want to be safe when delivering and preparing food and we feel these measures are necessary for those that want to dine out and return to a normal way of life. If you can not reach the restaurant, please leave a message on our office phone (561) 364-4083 and we will return your call as soon as we can. Kim Kelly -Owner PLEASE NOTE:* Regarding the safety of these items, written information is available upon request. * Consuming raw or undercooked meats poultry seafood shellfish or eggs may increase your risk of foodborne illness, especially if you have certain medical conditions.
